channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Explosion Reported in Kabul
item.description: A police official said a bomb exploded on the western edge of Afghanistan’s capital near the site of next week’s meeting to discuss a security pact with the United States.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Worst-Hit Area of Tacloban, a Killer From Two Sides
item.description: Barangay 88, which sits on a peninsula and is one of Tacloban’s most populous neighborhoods, endured massive destruction by last week’s typhoon.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mary Grace Golondrina, 20, held her trophy that she found in the debris of her house on Saturday in San Jose village in Tacloban, the Philippines.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: To a Philosopher-General in Israel, Peace Is the Time to Prepare for War
item.description: The departing commander of Israel’s Army in northern Galilee, Brig. Gen. Herzl Halevi, is convinced that Israel will go to war again with Lebanon.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The interesting issue is how you create a longer gap between the wars,” said Brig. Gen. Herzl Halevi.

item.title: Out of Europe’s Jobs Crisis, Voices of the Young
item.description: The New York Times asked young people in Europe to share their stories about how the crisis has affected their lives. Here is a selection of the responses.

item.title: Japan Backs Off From Emissions Targets, Citing Fukushima Disaster
item.description: Tokyo’s decision to no longer adhere to its plan could complicate efforts to forge a global climate change pact.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI and DAVID JOLLY

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: 4 Said to Recruit for Syrian War
item.description: Authorities have arrested four men suspected of involvement in a network sending fighters to Syria to join radical Sunni Islamist groups, the Paris prosecutor’s office said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Libya: U.S. Offers Rewards in Benghazi
item.description: The State Department said it had been quietly offering rewards of up to $10 million for information about last year’s attack on an American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Toronto Council Curbs Mayor
item.description: A special session of the Toronto City Council removed Mayor Rob Ford’s power to appoint some city officials, after he admitted using crack cocaine and binge drinking.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: 69 Political Prisoners Freed
item.description: The move came as part of a promise by Myanmar’s president to free all such detainees by the end of the year.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Boat Accident Kills 12 Migrants
item.description: Twelve migrants, believed to be Syrians, were found dead after a plastic boat still tied to rocks capsized in calm weather, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 7 Killed in Sectarian Clash
item.description: Shiites traveling in a religious procession near Pakistan’s capital killed seven Sunnis from an Islamic seminary for insulting them as they passed, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Arrests Begin in Vote-Fraud Case
item.description: The federal police began arresting a dozen powerful political figures, bankers and businessmen convicted in a vast vote-buying scandal that surfaced more than eight years ago.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: African Call to Delay Kenyans’ Trials Fails at U.N.
item.description: The International Criminal Court’s charges of crimes against humanity has led to tension with the African Union.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Relief Proceeds Slowly in Philippines, Where a Death Toll Remains Unclear
item.description: The search for bodies continued in Tacloban and nearby cities and towns as thousands of residents remained hungry and homeless.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boys covered their noses from the smell of bodies in Tacloban on Friday.

item.title: Libya Protest Turns Deadly as Militias Open Fire
item.description: Dozens of people were killed in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, setting off some of the worst violence there since the revolt against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi almost three years ago.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Albania Won’t Aid in Destruction of Syria’s Chemical Arms
item.description: The decision dealt a blow to Washington’s efforts to find a country prepared to undertake the politically sensitive disarmament project.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Beheading in Syria Is Called a Mistake
item.description: Jihadists in Syria beheaded a half-conscious man believed to be an enemy combatant and a Shiite — only to find that he was a rebel fighter, too.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: Young and Educated in Europe, but Desperate for Jobs
item.description: High unemployment in countries like Spain, Portugal and Greece is hitting young people hardest as they take jobs below their skill level and seek work abroad.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Europe's fiscal crisis has forced young people like Melissa Abadía to make painful adjustments and migrate to find jobs.

item.title: Death After the Typhoon: ‘It Was Preventable’
item.description: During five days in a Philippine hospital, a 27-year-old farmer and family breadwinner received virtually no care and died, in essence, of a broken leg.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marycris Pulga wept on Friday beside the body of her husband, Richard, at St. Paul's Hospital in Tacloban, the Philippines.

item.title: Students Try to Occupy Bulgarian Parliament Building
item.description: The action was the latest of a series of angry demonstrations against the center-left government of Prime Minister Plamen Oresharski.
item.dc:creator: By MAX RIVLIN-NADLER and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: French Say Kidnapped Priest Was Moved to Nigeria
item.description: The priest, who was seized in Cameroon, appears to have been taken by militants who are lashing out at France for financial and ideological reasons.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Compromise May Be Near for Iran Nuclear Deal, U.S. Official Says
item.description: American officials appear to be seeking a solution in which Iran would be allowed to enrich uranium at the low level of 3.5 percent during an interim agreement and also under a comprehensive accord.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: 22-Year-Old Wins a Big Game in Chess Championship
item.description: Magnus Carlsen of Norway leads 3 to 2 against the titleholder, Viswanathan Anand, the champion since 2007.
item.dc:creator: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: What Is the Value of Stolen Art?
item.description: Making money from stolen paintings — particularly famous ones — is not a straightforward matter.
item.dc:creator: By ED CAESAR
item.media:description: The space where a Matisse painting hung in the Kunsthal museum in Rotterdam, the day it and six other artworks were stolen.

item.title: In Economic Review, Italy and Spain Get Warnings on Debt and Deficit
item.description: Europe’s top economic official said the two countries risked missing debt and deficit targets.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
